Deliver the next generation of banking experiences!

Welcome to the 2016 Backbase Hackathon in Amsterdam and online, a two-day challenge to test your ideas and compete with your peers on 24th and 25th of June 2016.

Early bird registration is open!

Challenge: Accepted

The Backbase Hackathon is a chance for developers from all the Backbase locations to create something the banking industry has never-before seen. Do you have an idea you think others will love? Race against the clock to realise your dreams using whatever tools necessary! It’s a great opportunity to delve into open APIs and technologies to create new applications for banking customers, businesses or even your own colleagues.

The Ones to Beat

Last year, 15 teams competed to hack the financial system. In the end, team Exodus took the prize with their 3D-printed piggy bank that counted the actual coins you were saving up. This information was registered and sent to the online banking platform, which displayed a real-time balance to help children learn the benefits of saving up their pennies.

Backbase 2015 Hackathon Trailer

Think you can do better? Let’s see what you’ve got!

Who can take part?

All Backbase employees wherever you are, and also our near-shore partners are able to sign up. Whether you’re part of R&D, Sales, PS….everyone is welcome! We’ll have webcams set up so everyone can talk to and gently provoke encourage each other.

Hackathon Competition Scope

Can you believe a year has passed since the last Backbase Hackathon? I know, us too! This time, we intend to build on last year’s success by inviting even more of you to show off your skills, share your knowledge, and encourage a fun, learning environment that disrupts the banking industry. After all, that’s why we do this, right?

Compete in one of these categories:

Freestyle: Hack the banking industry

The freestyle category lets you run wild with your imagination and skills, with basic help if required. The goal is to disrupt the banking industry. To help you with this, you can use our Breeze API or any standalone model (if needed).

About Breeze API: URL to Breeze server: Documentation of Breeze API can be found here. (to be updated!)

Tags: Banking/Freestyle

Last year, the team Exodus 5:7 had 3D-printed a piggy bank that counts coins as they fall in. This information is registered and sent to the online banking platform, which then displays a real-time actual balance. Together with this, the team created a special (and extremely simplified) interface designed for kids, to begin understanding simple concepts such as having to wait to get something you want.

Build on top of the Backbase Platform

In this category, the aim is to improve the Backbase Platform by getting under their skin and hacking them! There are plenty of areas to tackle, such as CX Services, our Mobile or Web SDK, the Widget Collections, Manager, Forms, plus all Backbase internal (dev) tools. This is a chance to walk the talk and enhance the Backbase product experience for everyone!

Tags: Backbase Products/Add-ons/Improvements

For example: The goal of the El Corteso project last year was to create a plug-able module for the Backbase Android library to enable Backbase-powered mobile apps to be able to communicate with Android smartwatch apps. For this purpose, a smartwatch app with two functionalities was created, in order to display banking information from the mobile app, and enable the user to find the closest ATM. The smartwatch app was connected to a mobile device and communicated via the Backbase-powered app.

Upgrade our systems

This final category offers an opportunity to greatly improve the experience of being a Backbase employee. You can do this by hacking our time tracker tool, for instance, or an Atlassian extension, or any internal system or workspace improvement. There’s so much potential to make things better for everyone, and this is your canvas to do so. Let the painting begin!

Tags : Workspace/Communication/Employee Experience/Internal tools

For example: The goal of Happy Tree Friend’s project was to encourage cross-departmental collaboration at Backbase. The team added gamification to pull-requests, and created a dashboard of rich visualisations for the game. For each pull request, a developer gets one point, but in order to encourage cross-team pull requests, if the request comes from another team, the developer gets a bonus 10 points. Management can also decide on a set of featured repositories, where contributors get double points. At the end of each month, the developer with the most points wins. Developers can also become ‘king’ of a repository if they have the most contributions, and be awarded badges when they unlock different achievements.

Need some inspiration?

Just in case you are stuck for ideas on what to develop at the Backbase Hackathon, here are a few areas to consider and get your creativity to sparkle...

See the examples from 2015

Stock Tracker

  • Use the Backbase Mobile SDK to create a new stock tracker app that visualizes how people look at their portfolio in a completely different way.

Analytics Power!

  • Add a new Analytics App to Manager 5.6 that consumes the most needed reports from Google Analytics, in real time.

Bank 10.0

  • Visualize how the Bank of The Future would look like and create a Theme to make it real. Inspiration?

...and many more!

Join us on this 2-day hackathon in Amsterdam!

The 2nd Edition of the Backbase Hackathon invites you to apply today. Don’t waste time! Get this form filled in as soon as possible! The aim is to compete, so we can innovate together and move digital banking forwards. Here are some simple rules to abide by:

  1. Fresh hacking - This means you must present a brand new product or feature that didn’t exist before. Your hack must be crafted entirely during the hackathon.
  2. Work from a Backbase location – You can join the Hackathon remotely from any Backbase location. Please bring your own laptop.
  3. Sign up as a team – A team can consist of 1-5 members, and can comprise a mix of talents. For instance, a team could include a coder, a user experience expert, or an entrepreneur – any flavor will do.

At the end of the Hackathon, each team leader will present a 7-minute prototype demo to a jury of Backbase managers, as well as representatives of the Hackathon sponsor company.

Still left to happen!

APIs you might want to use

World Bank

The World Bank currently has three different APIs to provide access to different datasets: one for Indicators (or time series data), one for Projects (or data on the World Bank’s operations), and one for the World Bank financial data (World Bank Finances API).

All three APIs implement RESTful interfaces to allow users to perform queries of available data using selection parameters.

The World Bank Indicators API lets you programmatically access more than 8,000 indicators and query the data in several ways, using parameters to specify your request. Many data series date back 50 years, and can be used to create interesting applications.

Open Bank Project

Use a standard and hassle-free banking API

Want to develop a financial application which accesses bank account transactions? The Open Bank Project offers an easy-to-use RESTful JSON API. Connect in minutes and start using it.

With the Open Bank Project you can:

  • Integrate bank account information via our REST API
  • Use secure authentication via our OAuth implementation
  • Write once - run it everywhere.
  • Leverage a consistent and bank-agnostic interface

Plaid

Plaid’s custom bank access, rich transaction data, and robust security

Get bank account data you can actually use. Plaid translates data into human-readable form and layers on context so you can serve your customers better.

Open Financial Exchange

Open Financial Exchange (OFX) is a unified specification for the electronic exchange of financial data between financial institutions, businesses and consumers via the Internet.

OFX also supports making bill payments, stop a check, intrabank and interbank transfers etc. It is quite extensive.
See it here: http://ofx.net/AboutOFX/ServicesSupported.aspx

FRED API

FRED stands for Federal Reserve of Economic Data. It’s a web service that contains frequently updated US macro and regional economic time series at annual, quarterly, monthly, weekly, and daily frequencies. FRED also aggregates economic data from a variety of sources, most of which are US government agencies.

FRED serves those data via API, in JSON and XML formats. You can use it for free, just registering to get an API key. More information at the API doc page.

Quandl: https://www.quandl.com/blog/getting-started-with-the-quandl-api

Quandl is a data platform. They also host data from hundreds of publishers on a single easy-to-use website. They help data analysts save time, effort and money, by delivering financial and economic data in the format we want into dozens of tools.
